software.title: Scratch.MIT.edu
software.text: Simple 2D game design. Great for learning the basics, though usually the product you produce isn't as cool looking as what other tools would let you make. Plug 'n' play style coding, not quite the same as writing your own code, but a good starting place.

software.title: Alice.org
software.text: Simple 3D game design. Teaches programming logic and concepts using Plug 'n' play style coding.

links.title: Extra-Credits.net
links.text: If you have any interest in working in the video game industry, do yourself a favor and watch EVERY episode of this show. It's a 6 minute weekly cartoon that discusses every aspect of video games and the games industry.

links.title: Developer Valve Software
links.text: Great resource for learning about game development and modding using Valve's Source engine (used in Half-Life 2, Portal 2, Team Fortress 2, Left 4 Dead, etc).

terminology.title: 2D Terms
terminology.text: Raster, Bitmap, canvas, layers, gradient, alpha, channels, curves, hue, levels, histogram, exif, photo RAW, lossless, lossy

terminology.title: Vector Terms
terminology.text: Vector, path, anchor point, bezier curve, compound path, clipping mask

terminology.title: Animation Terms
terminology.text: Onion Skin, Pre-Comp, Squash & Stretch, keyframes, velocity, easing, frame rate, previsualization, storyboard

terminology.title: 3D Terms
terminology.text: Polygonal Mesh, NURBS, Subdivision Surface, Voxel, Subsurface scattering, render, refraction, bump map, texture, radiosity, raytrace

terminology.title: Video Terms
terminology.text: codec, wrapper, cut, lower thirds, b-roll, jump cut, encoding, bitrate, title safe

resources.title: Lynda.com
resources.text: The most comprehensive resource for learning software. Not free however. Watch the series for whatever software interested you from the above list.

resources.title: Revision3.com/PixelPerfect
resources.text: Photoshop lessons from a Photoshop Hall of Fame master (less than 30 people in the world have been given this title by Adobe). Designed for complete beginners.

software.title: Krita
software.text: Krita is the spiritual successor to the long outdated GIMP project. It's an open source image editor and the closest thing you can get to Photoshop for free. Though it's not as powerful. Still though, for learning the basics, this is not a bad place to start.

terminology.title: 2D Terms
terminology.text: Raster, Bitmap, canvas, layers, gradient, alpha, channels, curves, hue, levels, histogram, exif, photo RAW, lossless, lossy

java.title: NodeJS
java.text: Node allows you to write JavaScript outside of a browser. It has become a very popular server-side language for websites and is also used for cross-platform desktop application development using NW.JS (nwjs.io).

java.title: Processing
java.text: This is a language that's meant to quickly create visual elements from code. It's less about a functional end product, and more about visualizing data, or sketching an idea with code.

java.title: SQLBolt
java.text: When it comes to working with databases SQL (pronounced 'Sequel') is very common. There are many popular SQL databases including SQLite, MySQL, Postgres, Oracle and Microsoft SQL Server. SQLBolt does a fantastic job introducing you to these concepts

comparisons.title: LangPop.com
comparisons.text: Language popularity comparison using several measurements.

resources.title: PluralSight.com
resources.text: Great site for learning details of programming languages. Used by professional developers.

resources.title: TeamTreehouse.com
resources.text: Great for web designers and developers. The best site for learning the fundamentals of HTML, CSS, Responsive Web Design, and Ruby. Free trial, $9/month for students.
